posts.name: Aidan Mundy
posts.cooked:
We recently decided to have 3 coprocessors on the robot where we had previously planned for 2, meaning we no longer have an extra spot in our 5 port network switch (3 coprocessors, 1 rio, 1 radio) where we can plug in the driver station for tethered operation. We could just unplug the radio when running tethered, but we would prefer a dedicated tethering port.

Would a configuration like this with two Brainbox (or other brand) network switches work?:

Switch 1

RIO

Radio

Tether

Switch 2

Switch 2

Coprocessor 1

Coprocessor 2

Coprocessor 3

Switch 1

Or an alternative configuration: Switch 1

Radio

Tether

Switch 2

Switch 2

RIO

Coprocessor 1

Coprocessor 2

Coprocessor 3

Switch 1

posts.name: Carlos Gross Jones
posts.cooked:
Yep, that would work fine. Although, just for the sake of easy troubleshooting and having one less thing to worry about, it might be worth looking for an 8-port switch.

I’d prefer your first configuration to your second one. In the second, a failure of either switch would disconnect your radio from your RIO.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.custom_user_title: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.name: Aidan Mundy
posts.cooked:
Yeah the troubleshooting fallback here is “just use one of the switches”. We’ll definitely be looking into alternative switch options next year if multicam April tags continue to be popular, but no dice in the budget this year to try a new option and have to deal with external power regulation on top of that.

Thanks!

posts.cooked:

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
CarlosGJ:

failure of either switch would disconnect your radio

good observation and OP can push even further in that direction of considering failure modes:

Switch 1 - critical loads

RIO

Radio

1st most important coprocessor

2nd most important coprocessor

Switch 2

Switch 2 - secondary loads

3rd most important coprocessor

tether

Switch 1

posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked:
As a team that routinely runs a datacenter with far too many degrees of freedom, it would be my recommendation to run a single switch and not multiple.

We are looking at using these TP-Link Litewave switches this year: Amazon.com

We have not run these in competition yet but I’ve been sufficiently mean enough to one to want to try it out.  They weigh next to nothing and they seem quite good at being switches.

The 8 port is 9V and not 5V powered (like the 5 port) but we found both to have their barrel jacks easily removed with a soldering iron and replaced with an appropriate regulator from Pololu.

YMMV but you really want to reduce the number of failure points and not add to them.

I also like the TP-Link SG108E with a 12v to 9v converter that way we can test the Ethernet cables on the bot without disconnecting them from the bot, and limit bandwidth to be under the cap taking that load off of the radio. You can also deprioritize MJPEG traffic from your streams.

posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked:
Yeah… I’d be really hesitant to recommend that or do that at all.

A managed device is just one more thing that can go wrong with a misconfiguration.

Further, given how most switches implement bandwidth limiting, it’s not a standard process and there is a higher chance you could delay one of the control packets to the robot.

Again, YMMV but you really want to reduce the number of failure points and not add to them.
